rounds.observation:
[GAME] You are Player 0 in Tic Tac Toe.
Your goal is to win three in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) on the board.
On your turn, you should select the square number (0-8) you want to put your mark in next.
For example, '[4]' places your mark in the center cell of the board.

As Player 0, you will be 'O', while your opponent is 'X'.

[GAME] Current Board:

 0 | 1 | 2 
---+---+---
 3 | 4 | 5 
---+---+---
 6 | 7 | 8 

Available Moves: '[0]', '[1]', '[2]', '[3]', '[4]', '[5]', '[6]', '[7]', '[8]'
rounds.response:
I’m the first mover, so any square is available.  
The traditional optimal opening is the center, because it is part of four possible winning lines (middle row, middle column, both diagonals), which maximizes future threats and minimizes the opponent’s comeback chances.

[4]

rounds.response:
Current threats check:
1) Player 0 (O) has a strong diagonal threat from top-left to bottom-right (squares 0-4-8).  
   Square 0 is already X, so this diagonal is safe.
2) Player 0 has another diagonal (top-right to bottom-left: 2-4-6).  
   Square 4 is already O, square 2 is X, so this diagonal is also safe.  
3) The vertical right edge (squares 2-5-8) has X at 2 and O at 8: no win yet.  
4) The only remaining serious threat is for O to complete a row or column.  
   Looking down the right column (squares 2-5-8), square 5 is still free; if O lands there, it doesn’t immediately create three.  
   Looking across the bottom row (squares 6-7-8), O already holds 8; square 6 or square 7 would finish that row.

Player 0 should block any possible future fork for X while still pressing an offensive path.  
Placing O at square 6 both prevents X from taking that spot and gives O a direct path along the bottom row (6-7-8 with 8 already O).  
It also leaves the right column (2-5-8) open for future exploitation.

[6]
